titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Lucas left us, and a new Black man came in his stead; who goes by the name of Nelson, and says he came from the Island of Trinidad— The Trustees of the agricultural Society dined this day at Quincy, with my father— I went out with Mrs: Adams, and made part of the Company— We returned this Evening— I was a short time this morning attending at the District Court— Mr: S. Ripley, returned this morning from Washington— Mrs: Johnson was to have come with him, but eventually concluded not to come— He was here this afternoon, while we were absent; but was gone upon our return.

2. There was a cry of Fire last Night, between 12 and 1. O’Clock; and this morning Mr Lovell called upon me to make some enquiries respecting the time when Nelson came to my house last Night— The fire was at Mr: Hunt’s, the house from which he had come, and Mr: Lovell seemed to labour under some suspicion of him— I told him I had bolted my back door about 11. last Night; and told him he might go to bed—had left him in the kitchen, and heard him soon after four this morning come down from his chamber— He said he had been an excellent servant to Mr: Hunt, but in one instance had been furious in his Passion, and threatened the maid-servant with a knife— That he had left Mr: Hunt’s house in Anger, and that being a West-India black-man, some suspicion of him had arisen, the fire having commenced in an out-house— He thought however that this must be an error— As the grounds were too slight, and the evidence next to demonstration that he had been all Night here— I had been wide awake the whole Night after the fire, and once got up, and went to my front door to fix the blinds— This incident detained me at home the forenoon— Heard Mr: Buckminster at our own meeting-house this afternoon— Read a Sermon of Massillon—the Thursday after Ash Wednesday; on infidelity. Resumed George’s Instruction— Walk in the Mall— Overpowered with sleepiness almost all the day.

3. Engaged almost all the morning at home. Then attended at the District Court untill 3 O’Clock in the afternoon— Called at Mr: Shaw’s Office— On coming home I found Mr: De Grand at my house, and a Mr: Barrett, a son of the late Mr: Samuel Barrett: who wishes to consult me, on some business of his own— Appointed to meet him at my Office the day after to-morrow— This Evening Mrs: Adams, and Catherine passed at Dr: Welsh’s— I went there to them, after passing about an hour walking in the Mall with Mr: G. Blake— After I came home, about 10. in the Evening a couple of boys came to my house and left with me a
National Intelligencer of 28 June, requesting me after I should have looked over it, to send it to the Palladium Office— I found in it a paragraph, that on the day before, that is, the 27th: of June the Senate had confirmed the nomination of John Quincy Adams, as Minister Plenipotentiary to the Court of St: Petersbourg; by a vote of 19. to 7.— I sent the newspaper to the Palladium-Office, but knew not who the boys were that brought it to me.

4. My father arrived in town early this morning— And at 10. O’Clock I went with him to the Senate chamber, in the State-house, from which, a procession of the Governor and Council, with the Selectmen of the Town, and a numerous company, went to the Old South church; where the Town Oration was delivered by Mr: William Tudor junr:— While in the Church, and immediately after the delivery of the Oration, Mr: Shaw gave me several letters, one of which was from the Secretary of State, enclosing the Commission to St: Petersbourg— The others were from Mr: Giles, Mr: Anderson, Mr: Bacon, and my nephew William S. Smith, at New-York— After the Oration the company invited by the Governor and Council returned to the State-house, and partook of a Collation— I saw there Mr: Lovell, who told me that he and Mr: Hunt were perfectly satisfied that the suspicions he had mentioned respecting Nelson, were all groundless— The second procession, that of the Bunker-Hill Association went from the Representatives chamber, soon after the other had returned to the State-House— I joined them according to the invitation I had received, and walked with Mr: G. Blake— The procession, with various emblems of Agriculture, Commerce and Manufactures, and consisting of about five hundred persons, including three militia-companies went through the town, over Charles river Bridge, to Bunker’s Hill, where a dinner was prepared under an arbour, covered with a tent and four rows of tables for the Company.— Deacon Tilden was the President. Mr: W. C. White who at 9 in the morning had delivered an Oration to the Association was of the party— The toasts after dinner were many of them too much in the usual stile of party, on these occasions— Mr: Jonn: L. Austin came and told me that he had a son, who would be glad to go with me, as my Secretary, but the application was too late— Early in the Evening I left the Company at Bunker-Hill, with Mr: Blake, and we went with Mr: Blake to pay a visit to the young Republicans assembled at the Exchange-Hotel; to make which visit I had received a special invitation— We stayed there only a few minutes to reciprocate salutations and give toasts, after which we retired. Walking in the Mall, I met Mr: John Gardner, and walked sometime with him— I asked him why I had not seen him for so many days, and he told me that he had been unwell, and out of town. We walked some time together, and witness’d the fire-works, which were exhibited on the Common— About ten at Night I returned home, and found that my father was gone, on his return to Quincy, and that Mrs: Adams and Catherine were at my neighbour Mr: William Foster’s— I went there, and found them with all the family, on the top of his house looking at the fire-works— They were principally from the gun-house, and the rockets sent up, came down in blazing paper and burning sticks upon the house itself and several of the neighbouring houses and yards, including mine—in a manner which I thought dangerous— No accident of fire however ensued. I found at home a letter from Mr: A. H. Everett requesting me to take him with me as my Secretary— This application was also too late.

5. This morning early Dr: John C. Howard called at my house, and told me that he came to talk with me about our old friend John Gardner; he asked me if I was acquainted with his condition— I said I had very lately been informed that his misfortunes had depress’d him to that degree, that he had unfortunately fallen into a habit of intemperance, and that still more recently I had perceived symptoms of it in reality; at which I was excessively concerned and shocked— He said that his character was so totally broken down and degraded that he could not appear in the Streets in open day, and that he dared not meet the eyes of his friends. That nothing could save him from destruction, but going abroad somewhere; and under these Circumstances the Dr: asked me if I could not take him with me as my Secretary— I answered that my affection for Mr: Gardner would induce me to do any thing for him in my power consistent with my duties to others— But that the very Circumstances stated by Dr: Howard himself must operate as a total prohibition to me to take him with me— That if I should with open eyes, voluntarily connect with an important public trust, a man in such a situation, I should be as unable afterwards to meet the eyes of my friends, as he of his— That if any manner of redeeming him from his condition could be devised, to which I could contribute my aid, it should cheerfully be given— But to take him to a foreign Country, in a situation where the interest and character of our own might in
in some sort be staked upon his conduct, was utterly impossible— Dr: Howard admitted the force of the principle, but seemed not altogether satisfied as to the effect— Soon after breakfast young Mr: Aspinwall called upon me, and proposed himself to me for the same office as my Secretary. I gave him the same answer as to the others since I received William S. Smith’s letter (Dr: Howard excepted.) I answered the Secretary of State’s letter enclosing the commission, and accepted the office. It is with a deep sense of the stormy and dangerous career upon which I enter; of the heavy responsibility that will press upon it, and of the unpromising prospect which it presents in perspective. My personal motives for staying at home are of the strongest kind;—the age of my Parents, and the infancy of my children both urge to the same result— My connection with the College, is another strong tie which I break with great reluctance; and by refusing the Office I should promote my personal popularity more than by accepting it— In my own opinion also, I could do more public service here in a private Station, than abroad upon this mission— To oppose all this, I have the duty of a Citizen to obey the call of his Country, signified by the regular Constitutional authority; the Satisfaction of being removed at least for a time, and with honour from a situation, where the deepest retirement has not sheltered me from the most virulent and unrelenting Persecution, and the vague hope of rendering to my Country some important service, as intended by the mission—finally the desire to justify the confidence reposed by Mr: Madison in me, by assuming the Station which he has chosen to assign to me, and by devoting all my powers to the support of his administration, so far as it shall aim, as I am perfectly convinced it does and will aim, at the welfare of this whole Union— These are my motives— And I implore the blessing of Almighty God, upon this my undertaking— That all its critical moments may find me in possession of myself—in possession of the virtues, which contribute all that human power can contribute to success—and prepared alike for whatever Event his Providence destines for its termination— Finally with the profoundest sense of Gratitude, for that goodness, which has so far rescued from its perils my beloved Country, and from perils not less menacing my own person and reputation, with the people of America, I humbly ask for perfecting goodness; for the entire extrication of my Country from her difficulties and dangers, and for myself the continued consciousness of purity in my motives, and so far as it has been or may be deserved, the approbation of my Countrymen.

I answered my young friend Everett, like the rest—that the appointment of my Secretary had been engaged from the time I had received W. S. Smith’s letter, which was the first application— He was extremely disappointed, but acquiesced in the determination— In the course of the day I received a letter from Mr: J. Gardner, proposing to me, at the suggestion of a friend this morning to go with me, and desiring to converse with me on the subject— In the Evening I attended club at Dr: Eliot’s— Mr: Quincy was there, just returned from Congress— I spoke again to Dr: Howard, as we were returning home this Evening, about Mr: Gardner— I told him, that independent of the objection I had mentioned to him this morning, there was another, that I had previously engaged the place— That this would be my answer to Mr: Gardner himself, as it was a difficulty equally insuperable with the other.

div.p:
6. Mr: Barrett called upon me this day, upon some Law business— He had called yesterday as I had appointed, and being detained at home I was not at my Office— He brought me this day his papers— I am to draw a petition for him— Dr: Waterhouse called at my house this day after dinner, and said he would call for me to-morrow between twelve and one O’Clock, to go with him to Cambridge— I wrote my resignation of the Professorship to carry it with me to the President to-morrow.— There was a meeting this afternoon at 4. O’Clock of a number of Gentlemen, at the Representatives chamber in the State-house to form a Society for distributing the Bible, which I attended— The Society was formed and adjourned to this day week, to receive the report of a Committee— Mr: Buckminster asked me in behalf of Everett, if I had fixed upon my only Secretary, and said Everett had desired him to speak a word for him being anxious to an extreme to go with me— I assured him of my strong wish to gratify him; but could only refer to the limitation of my powers— Buckminster
also named William Tudor, as being extremely well qualified for the place, and desirous of going— But he said he was aware the same answer must apply to him— I was a short time this day at the District Court.— Judge Davis spoke to me about Dexter’s argument on the unconstitutionality of the Embargo Laws; about which he said he had this day given an explanation— I received this day a letter from Genl: Saml: Smith of Baltimore, urging me to take his son John with me as my Secretary; but he to be entirely at his own expence of living &c— In the Evening walking in the Mall I saw a man walking up the gravel-walk, apparently in much agitation, talking aloud to himself, with considerable gesticulation— After walking some time in a line parallel to him I perceived it was Mr: Gardner— I accosted him, and from that moment he appeared altogether rational and walked with me perhaps an hour or more. I left him about 10 O’Clock. On going home I found Mr: A. H. Everett at my house; he stay’d and supp’d with us; and untill midnight— Mr: William Foster junr: and his lady had been most of the Evening at our house— Both soliciting for him to go as my Secretary— Mrs: Adams answered them for me— At Night, Mrs: Adams told me that she had seen Mrs: Whitcomb— That Mr: Gardner lodged there— That he was occasionally raving, when alone; and especially at Night— That two Night’s ago he had been so loud as to rouse the whole house, and that Dr: James Jackson & Mr: Charles Jackson had been sent for to him— And had come— But that whenever any person was with him he was gentle, and altogether rational— I am deeply apprehensive that his understanding is disordered.— He had called at my Office this day, and I had given him the answer, on his application, with which he instantly acquiesced.

div.p:
7. I was early this morning at my Office and saw Mr: Barrett— Mr: William Gray called to enquire at what hour we proposed to go out to Quincy.— Mrs: Sullivan had sent to propose to Mrs: Adams to go out with her this afternoon on a visit to my mother.— Mrs: Adams had agreed to go, and called upon Mrs: Gray to invite her also to go— Mrs: Gray was going to Salem, and could not be of the party, but Mr: Gray supposing I was going also engaged to go— But I was obliged to attend at Cambridge, and therefore could not go to Quincy— Mr: Gray went with Mrs: Adams and Catherine— While he was with me I made some enquiries of him, whether I could get an opportunity of a passage, direct for St Petersbourg— He said he had one or more vessels now here, and could put a cargo in one of them in five days time— That it would suit his convenience to load it for that place as well as any other, and that he would do it with pleasure, if we could sail before the last of this Month, after which it would be too late for a navigation up the Baltic— He also made some proposals to me to take with me his son Francis, who leaves College this year, as a Secretary— I told him of the engagements I had made, but offered to take him on the same terms as I had agreed to take the son of Genl: S. Smith— That is that they should go altogether at their own expence, and occasion no charge to the Government.— He said he intended to have placed him in my Office, on his leaving College, if I had remained at home, and he should wish him to go with me, as I was going abroad. The expence was no object to him— Mr: Everett on finding the engagements I had made with regard to those two Gentlemen now applied to know whether I would take him in the same manner, to which I consented; but upon condition in all the cases that I should inform the Secretary of State of it, and that no objection by the President or by him should be made to it— I wrote accordingly this Evening— Dr: Waterhouse called at 1. and I went with him; dined at his house; attended the declamation at 2. O’Clock, and my Lecture 21. at 3.— The Dr: was in great agitation— He had just seen Genl: Dearborn the Collector, who on his letters from the Secretary of the Treasury, resulting from the investigation of the subjects on which complaint against the Doctor had been made, advised him to resign— He appeared to feel as if he had no other resource than to comply.— He said it had appeared to him that Genl: Dearborn had been prejudiced against him from the beginning— That Eustis had taken a violent part against him— That he did not like the idea of going through a trial by Commissioners— That Hastings had been ruined by it— He said perhaps in my absence, the Corporation and Overseers of the College would chuse an adjunct Professor to perform the duties, and asked if I had any objection to his making application for it to the Corporation— I told him I had my resignation written— That I had heard talk of some such project as he mentioned but should give no countenance to it, and therefore must specially request him not to make
make any application uponthat ground— He seemed to think that such an application would afford him an opportunity to resign with credit— I feel much for his distress, and the situation of his family; but cannot aid him in this manner— Between the Declamation and Lecture I called at the President’s to inform him of my resignation, but he was absent, at Boston; and I had accidentally left my letter at my Office— I walked from Cambridge into Town, and on the Bridge met Mr: Hastings who was going out to Cambridge where he now resides, and who enquired of me, whether I did not want to purchase a pew in Mr: Emerson’s meeting-house— I told him I had one for present use, and should not now have occasion to purchase— After my return, and while writing at my Office a Mr: Mowith, and a Mr: Tarbell came to me with a letter from T. Thomas of Newbury-Port, on some Law business connected with some which I transacted for a Mr: Brooking in 1802. They are to call (as well as Mr: Barrett, whose papers I have not yet drawn up,) to morrow morning.— The Ladies returned from Quincy about 9. this Evening.

8. At my Office this morning— Copied my letter to Secy: State, and put it into the Post-Office— Mr: Barrett called, and I finally gave him his petition, drawn up— He wishes also for a letter to the Secy: of the Treasury, which upon enquiry I shall give him— My Clients from Newbury-Port also came— I examined with them the records at the Probate-Office; but being unable further to attend to their business referred and introduced them to Mr: Jos: Hall, whom, not finding at his Office, I called out of Court, and to whom I made a statement of the case— I saw Mr: Charles Jackson, and told him what had occurr’d respecting his brother in Law Mr: Gardner, and that I was apprehensive his Understanding was affected— Mr: Jackson spoke of it rather dubiously; but said that there had been some singular appearances in his conduct noticed by his Sister last Summer, before the late crisis in his affairs— He now hinted to me for the first time a part of the subject, entirely new to me— That Gardner’s Accounts as a Manager of the College Lottery could not be settled, and that by the defalcation he had involved his father-in-Law Jackson, as his bondsman— This is a new Comment upon the proposal that I should take him with me as my Secretary, of which I was not before aware.— My brother and my Mother came to town this day, and dined with us— In the Evening I went to Quincy with my Mother— Mr: Jos: Hall had yesterday called upon me to recommend Gardner to me— I know he did not come of his own motion— But I know not at whose instance he did come. I have been some time occupied in a project to take down the house, where I keep my Office, and to rebuild it— Mr: Osgood the Mason was with me on the subject this day; and has my plans with him— But I think I shall postpone the undertaking to a time when I may be more able to accomplish it— I saw Mr: Gray this day, and enquired if his vessel, in case I should take passage in her, would accommodate all those who might go with me— He said she would.

9. Heard Mr: Flint of Cohasset both parts of the day— Employed the principal part of its remainder in writing to fill the arrearages of this book, which had run up in the course of the last week— The principal difficulty of Journalizing is that the time of the greatest and most important occupation is the time when the moments for recording them are hardest to be found. I received yesterday a letter from Mr: Lazell the Treasurer of the New-Bedford and Bridgewater Turnpike, giving me notice that they had directed him to sue the Subscribers who had not taken up their shares, and that he should sue me. I desired my brother this day to defend the suit for me, and gave him the substance of my defence— I also enquired of him, if Catherine Johnson, should not go with us, and could get no other convenient opportunity to return to Washington, whether he would go with her, which he promised— We bathed this Evening at Mr: Black’s wharf.

10. My father on the 4th: of July, took my son John out with him to Quincy, where he has been ever since— He has been unwell, with one of his severe hoarse fits— But has recovered— I saw him just before I got into Thayer’s Stage, in which I this day returned to Boston— Mr: Edward Jackson, Mr: Leonard Foster, and Mr Foster Coffin, have made application since Saturday, to know, if I had engaged my Secretary— Mr: Gerry, who has called several times before at my house, when I was absent, came at length to my Office, and enquired in behalf of a friend of his, whether there would be a Secretary of Legation to go with me— There is none— That office, would have suited his friend; but not that of private Secretary—whence I suppose the person to be his son in Law J. T. Austin— I received also a letter from Mr: John Wadsworth at Portland— I saw
saw Mr: Osgood, and concluded not to proceed with my building project.— The Excessive heat of this afternoon disabled me, from doing any thing of consequence— I bathed this Evening at the Stairs in Charles-Street, which are now restored. Catherine Johnson dined at Mr: Foster’s, and went on a party with Mrs: Otis to Cambridge, this afternoon. I called at Mr: Gore’s to give up the pew at Mr: Emerson’s Meeting-house, but he was not at home.

div.p: 11. I am this day forty-two years of age— And the reflections which return at every anniversary of my birth day, naturally recur, with increasing pressure— The year of my life now expiring has been marked by a continuance of that persecution which the combined personal enemies of my father and myself, had unrelentingly pursued the year before. It has appeared in various forms, some of them singular enough; but its effect has been to impel me into more general notice and estimation throughout the Country.— I have now just received an appointment of great trust and Importance, totally unsolicited, and confirmed by every vote in Senate, excepting my personal enemies, and two others, who voted not against me, but against the mission. Mr: Turner of North-Carolina, who voted against the nomination, express’d in the highest terms his approbation of the person.— With this Trust, my duties to my Country, bring again a burden of responsibility, which I ought perhaps to have declined— On the integrity of my Intentions, and on the aid of that Gracious Heaven which never has deserted me, I must rely— I pray for clearness of intellectual vision to see the right path—for the necessary courage to pursue it; and for the Fortitude and the Temperance to bear with equanimity the vicissitudes of its Fortunes, whether adverse or propitious. Grant, O God, that I may do Good to my Country and to Mankind!— And deal with me, and mine, if it be thy gracious will, in Mercy.

My brother and his wife came to town this day, dined with us, and returned at Night. He was with me at my Office the greater part of the day, and assisted me in taking the Catalogue of my Books there; which we completed. That of my Books at the house is yet to be taken— I called at Mr P. C. Brooks’s Office, and had some conversation with him about vesting some Stock for my father— I was engaged all the rest of the day in other arrangements preparatory to my departure, which will employ me the full remainder of the time I shall have here. In the morning I called on Mr: Jackson the Treasurer of the College; and afterwards delivered to Judge Davis, my letter of Resignation to the President, Corporation and Overseers— Mr: De Grand pass’d part of the Evening and supped with us.

12. I was confined at home all this day, untill the Evening, by a very severe Storm— Wind & Rain— Attended Club at Mr: Emerson’s, where the meeting was thin— Mr: W. Gray was of the Company— Mr: Everett was with me part of the day; assisting me in making the Catalogue of my books— He has concluded to go with me.

13. My brother came again to town this morning; and with Mr: Everett continued making out the Catalogue of my library. I was also employed great part of the morning in the same manner— I am also making preparation for leaving my affairs in the hands of my brother—and making an Inventory in a Book to be left with him— This afternoon my brother returned to Quincy in the Stage— I attended the meeting at the Bible Society, where the President and Officers were chosen, and the Subscription made— Spent the Evening with Mr: Parsons, the Chief-Justice, at his house.

div.p: 14. My brother came into town this morning with Louisa Smith and my son John— I received a letter from Mr: Daschkoff the Russian Chargé d’Affaires and Consul General just arrived in this country—which I answered. Doctor Waterhouse had engaged to call for me between 12 and 1. O’Clock, but was prevented from coming to town— I waited for him untill past one, and then took my brother’s Horse and Chaise, and went with them— At Vose’s I met Mr: Boylston whom I have not seen for several weeks— I found Dr: Waterhouse and his family at dinner; and was a few minutes late for the declamation— The Speakers were 17. more than I had ever heard at one time— It was half-past 3. when the declamation finished— I immediately read my lecture 22— And then returned to Boston— My brother returned with John to Quincy this Evening; leaving Louisa Smith here— I called at Mr: Emerson’s, but he was not at home.

div.p: 15. Called again on Mr: Emerson at his vestry, and asked him, if he could make a record in his Parish register, of my Marriage, and of the Baptism of my son George, which he consented to do; taking the facts from the Certificates of Mr: Hewlett, and of Mr: Proby.— I went to the Boston Bank, and to the several Insurance Companies where I hold Stock, and made the transfers of my father’s Stock, into his name— At the Custom-House, I gave General Dearborn the Collector, my answer to Mr: Daschkoff, requesting him to forward it to the Collector at Philadelphia, by this day’s Mail; which he promised. I was some time at my Office, writing— At the Fire and Marine Insurance Office— Bathed, with Mr: De Grand, about 2. and he came home, and dined with us.— This afternoon, Mr: Bird, one of the members of the Senior Class at College, came with a letter from a Committee of two of that and two of the Junior Class, expressing their regret, at the prospect of my departure, and a request that I would publish my lectures— I desired Mr: Bird to thank the two Classes for their obliging expressions, and with respect to the publication, which I had not contemplated, I must ask a little time for reflection, and would then give them an answer.— I walked this Evening in the Mall, and meeting Judge Davis, consulted him as a member of the Corporation, on the propriety of such a publication; he inclined in its favour; but said he would advise with other members of the Corporation, and proposed to me to speak about it to Mr: Parsons the Chief-Justice— I told him that if upon the whole, the Corporation should see any objection to the publication, I would certainly withhold it; as, from the imperfection of the work, my own inclination was rather against publishing, at least for the present.

16. Heard Mr: Emerson, the whole day— Employed the remaining part of it in writing, for various objects preparatory to my departure— William S. Smith, my sister’s eldest son arrived here this afternoon from New-York— I called in the Evening at Mr: Quincy’s house; but he has removed from town— I was afterwards an hour at Mr: S. A. Otis’s—who returned last Evening from Washington.

17. I attended some time this morning at my Office— Mr: Farrow, of the Company of Boott and Farrow, applied for the shop below. I saw Mr: Osgood the mason again; on the project of rebuilding my house in Court Street— He also called at my house upon it, but we did not agree upon our terms— Afternoon and Evening at home; confined by a storm of rain.— Writing, in my library— News this day arrived from Halifax, that the British Government had disavowed the transactions of their Minister Mr: Erskine, here last April.

18. Cold storm continued the whole of this day— Employed great part of the day in packing books and other Articles— This afternoon Mr: Everett brought me an Answer from the Secretary of State to my letters of the 5th: and 7th:— I met the Directors of the Boylston-Market Association—resigned my Office of President, and delivered to them the Treasurer’s Bond, and Seal of the Corporation— I afterwards called at Mr: W. Gray’s, to make some further arrangements with him for our sailing— These however are to be more particularly settled in future— I agreed to take passage with my family in his vessel.

19. The storm continued last night, and through the whole of this day— Mr: W. Smith went out to Quincy. I was very much engaged the whole day at home— In the Evening I met the club at Mr: Edward Gray’s— It was generally well attended. My preparations for my departure engross all my time; and I find myself specially embarrass’d with my library.

20. The storm has ceased, but the weather is still cold and gloomy; we had fires yesterday and this day.— Coll: Bradford, the Sheriff called this morning, and served upon me the writ of the New-Bedford & Bridgwater Turnpike Corporation. W. S. Smith returned from Quincy— My brother also was in town, with his wife; and called for a few minutes at my house— Mr: Loud of Weymouth was here in the afternoon, upon a claim which he has against the Russian Government— Mr: Ripley was also here— I sent six boxes of books to the Athenaeum, where they with the rest of my library, are to be deposited, untill my return home, or untill claimed by my legal representative— I called this Evening on chief Justice Parsons, and consulted him as a member of the Corporation respecting my lectures & their publication— He sees no objection to the publication.

div.p: 21. Engaged all the morning upon my books— Mr: Gilman called to pay me a visit. At noon Mr: Ripley called upon me, and after dining we went together to Cambridge— At 2. O’Clock I attended the Declamation which was very long— No delinquents; and twelve Speakers— Without leaving the Chapel, which was much crowded with Company, I read my 23d: Lecture— I gave Mr: Bird, my answer to the letter from the Students of the two Senior Classes— I called at Mr: Hilliard’s, and proposed to him to undertake the printing of my lectures— He said he would within a few days give me proposals for the publication— I returned to town with Mr: Dexter, in his Carriage— Went to his House, and saw his painted chamber, the effect of which is very pleasing— I then came home, and resumed the packing of my books; untill dark— Mr: S. A. Otis called to see me— I returned to Mr: W. Foster the papers of Law business which he had put into my hands; and called in the Evening at Mr: Gray’s to enquire respecting his vessel, and to agree on a time, when to go on board— We determined upon to-morrow at 12. O’Clock.— I received an answer from Genl: S. Smith of Baltimore; whose son accepts to go out with me, as I had proposed.

22. Still employed upon the books; and sent five boxes more of them this afternoon to the Athenaeum— At noon I went with Mr: W. Gray junr:—to Charlestown, and went on board the ship Horace, at the wharf— This is the vessel in which we propose to sail for St: Petersburg.— After returning, I saw Mr: White my neighbour, and had some conversation with him, respecting the rebuilding of my house in Court-Street; and the part of the partition Wall which is to be built— He said he would answer me on Tuesday— My Mother came into Town; and dined with us; and in the afternoon, I went out to Quincy with her; and took George with me— My whole time is engross’d in making arrangements of every kind for my departure

23. Heard Mr: Foster of Little-Cambridge the whole day— In the Evening I went to Mr: Whitney’s with my father, and engaged him to take George to School; immediately— I afterwards went to Mr: Cranch’s— Mrs: Cranch will take my two sons George and John, to board— I was employed all the leisure time of the day in settling the papers, for my father, and my brother.

24. Returned to Boston this morning in the Stage—sent off several more boxes of books to the Athenaeum; and was employed, most of the day in making the Catalogue, and packing the remainder— Engaged also in various other affairs—drawing papers—settling accounts &c. Mr: B. Austin called on me this afternoon, from a Committee of Republican Citizens with an invitation to a public dinner, and to enquire the day which would best suit me— I excused myself owing to the shortness of my time, and the pressure of my engagements— We were invited this Evening to a party at Mr: Emerson’s, but could not go— I pass’d it chiefly at Mr: Gray’s making arrangements for our departure.

25. Received this morning, a letter from the Secretary of State of the 20th: promising to forward my Instructions by the next days mail.— My brother came to town and dined with us— I finished most of my business with him; settled the account of my debt to my father and mother, and paid over the balance to him—gave him also the papers— Still engaged in the Catalogue, and packing the books— My brother returned to Quincy. In the Evening we were all at a party of Ladies and Gentlemen, at Mr: W. Gray’s where we supp’d— Saw Mr: Thorndike, on his business.

26. This day is the twelfth Anniversary of my Marriage. I received my Instructions from the Secretary of State; and other papers, all but the Credentials which are yet to come; directly from the President who is in Virginia. I received yesterday the invitation to the publick dinner, in writing; and answered it this morning.— Mrs: Adams and the family went out to Quincy, to my father’s— Mr: Gray, and part of his family were also there— They met there, Mr: Boudinot, Mrs: Bradford, and Miss Binney— I was so much engaged that I could not go— At home, writing all the afternoon— Evening at Club.— Heavy thunder-shower this afternoon.

27. Continued the making of the Catalogue, and packing of books to be sent to the Athenaeum. Called at the Academy’s Room in the State-House, and returned the books I had borrowed of them.— Saw there Dr: Lathrop, and President Webber, to whom I mentioned the intended publication of my Lectures, which they approved— I received several letters— Transacted the business, respecting my draft on the Secretary of State with Mr: Gray— At six this afternoon I went to Mr: Shaw’s Office, and there signed & published my Will.— Afterwards, attended the meeting of the Boylston Market Association—where my brother was unanimously chosen a Director, in my stead; and a vote of thanks to me was pass’d— Mr: & Mrs: W. Gray— Mr: Delort, and Mr: Charles Foster were part of the Evening at our house.

div.p: 28. After being very busily engaged all the morning, at 12. O’Clock, I went with W. S. Smith to Cambridge— My Mother, and brother came into Town, and went to Cambridge at the same time with us— We all dined at Mr: Wainwright’s; where there was a Company, of perhaps twenty persons— At 2. O’Clock, I attended the Declamation, which was not entirely full— At 3. I read my 24th: Lecture, at the close of which I added some thoughts on taking leave of the College. All the Classes attended, and the chapel was very much crowded with Strangers— I called afterwards at President Webber’s, where I met Dr: Lathrop and Mr: Stedman; and took leave of them all.— Then went to Mr: Hilliard’s, and made an agreement with him about printing my Lectures— He agreed to come to Boston on Monday, and execute the Papers— I afterwards called on Mr: Hedge, and at Dr: Waterhouse’s where there was Company— I had intended also calling at Judge Dana’s— But hearing he was at Porter’s Tavern, attending a Committee of the General Court, about a road I went and took leave of him there— Returned to Boston; and was employed all the Evening in writing, and making other preparations for my voyage.— I gave this day to Mr: G. W. Apthorp two Deeds in Trust, from him and his family to me, James Lloyd junr: and John Prince junr: which for several years have been deposited with me.

29. I received this morning from the Secretary of State, a letter, enclosing the credential to the Emperor of Russia, but hinting a doubt whether I could now go in any private vessel— I was a little embarrass’d to determine whether I should suspend my preparations for going, or continue them— I concluded to make them employ me two or three days longer, and still to sail, if I should not in that time hear again from Washington— I immediately saw Mr: Gray, and informed him of this State of things— I was engaged all the morning in a multiplicity of affairs— Dr: Eliot and Judge Thacher called to visit me and take leave— Coll: Boyd, and a lieutenant Adams had visited me yesterday, or the day before— My father came into town, and dined with us— As did Mr: & Mrs: Boylston— Mr: D. Everett was at my house after dinner, and requested a copy of my valedictory observations yesterday, to print in the Patriot— I told him I had no objection, but that Mr: Hilliard having now the Copy-right of the Lectures, I could not give any part of them without his consent— For which Mr: Everett said he would apply— I went with my father out to Quincy this Evening; taking papers to be drawn up, for which I should there be less interrupted—so as to lose no time.

30. Heard Mr: Whitney morning and afternoon— The remainder of the day, I was engaged, in drawing up papers which my brother assisted me in copying— Mr: and Mrs: Cranch, and Boylston Adams called in the Evening, and I took leave of them.

31. Took leave of my father, and of my two sons George and John, whom we leave at Mr: Cranch’s; and of my father’s family living with him; and returned to Boston in the Stage— I found Mr: Munroe, waiting at my door, for the copy, to print which they had obtained the consent of Mr: Hilliard— I lent him the Lecture itself, from which it is to be taken.— Mr: Hilliard himself came in soon after, and seemed to regret that he had consented; but concluded not to retract it— I executed the papers of our agreement, with him— Dr: Welsh was here, and I settled my debt to him— Called on Dr: Warren, and did the same with him.— Remainder of the day, engaged much in the same manner— Saw Messrs: Osgood and Whitney, and White with whom I am to execute Deeds which I have drawn up, but we were obliged to put off the execution untill to-morrow— Mr: Ripley pass’d the Evening and supp’d with us— Louisa Smith is with us also— Came into town last Evening— Mr: S. Dexter & Mr: James H. Foster, and his wife were here in the Evening—
Day— None regular.
